elements.text: Shoes made while you wait. Magic spells. Fish, fresh fish. So fresh they're still swimming. Magic spells, lucky charms.
Ah, the heady scent of culture.
Heady scent of fish, more like.
Oh, Evelyn, this is one of the birthplaces of civilisation.
Birthplace of civilisation? Hot pie stalls and lucky charm salesmen? Anyway, I thought the Roman Republic was all overthrowing kings and civil wars.
Well yes, there was the odd monarchical displacement, and perhaps an occasional military squabble, but it was also the time of Plato, Aristotle, Archimedes, Euclid.
None of whom was Roman.
Oh, very well, then. Catullus, Cicero, Caesar. All of whose cultural significance you surely cannot deny.
Don't get your toga in a twist. I give in. That is rather exciting. So, who are we going to visit first? Catullus? A nice bit of bawdy poetry to start us off?
Ah. Now, if the Tardis time monitor is correct, and I checked, and it is, he's been dead for half a century.
Er, Doctor, Catullus died in 54BC, not 154... Oops, have I just blown an important plot point? Sorry.
Cicero, then. We can chat about politics and philosophy.
The politics of the playground and the philosophy of early bedtime, perhaps.
What do you mean?
He'd be about five.
Ah. Oh. I don't think I'll even ask about Caesar.
It's 101 BC.
And Caesar was born?
In 100 BC.

One year out. Goodness, that means his parents are out there somewhere, with not an idea in the world that they're soon going to produce one of the most important figures in history. Someone whose name will be known for millennia to come. Julius Caesar!
Yes?
I beg your pardon?
You called my name. Julius Caesar.
Ah, I er (sotto) Doctor, you got it wrong.
(sotto) Don't think so. (normal) Evelyn, I believe we have the pleasure of meeting Senator Gaius Julius Caesar. (sotto) The elder.
Oh. Oh, how nice to meet you. We were just talking about you.
So I gathered. Might I be so bold as to enquire why?
Er, we were wondering how your wife was.
Oh, you know Aurelia? She is well. I have the most wonderful idea. Come and dine with us. Aurelia would be thrilled, er
I'm the Doctor, and this is Evelyn.
Doctor, Evelyn, do say yes. It would be so nice for Aurelia to see old friends.
We're not exactly
We'd be delighted. Come along, Evelyn.
Nearly there.
Lots of dogs barking.
This isn't what I expected at all. Did the first man in Rome really come from a place like this? Those high-rise flats. It's as if the Queen had given birth to Prince Charles in Hackney.
You're not far wrong. Very queen-like, Aurelia, by all accounts, for all that the family was impoverished.
This would be our old friend Aurelia? It's going to be rather embarrassing when she says she's no idea who we are.
Oh, we'll bluff it out. Besides, she'll be far too polite to mention it. Imagine what the Queen
would do.
(imitating) One has not the faintest clue who these commoners are. Orf with their heads.
That's the spirit.
Here we are.
Sorry, I get a bit puffed.
Well, do come in and sit down.
Door opens.
Aurelia, I've got a wonderful surprise for you.
(seductive) Hello, darling. Come here. I've been waiting for. (annoyed) Oh.
I've brought some old friends to see you. The Doctor and Evelyn.
Hello.
Hello.
Oh. Hello, Doctor. Evelyn. How nice to see you.
Yes. It's been an awfully long time. You probably don't even remember us.
No, no. How could I forget?
Do have a seat. Now, if you will excuse me for a moment, I just have a few small matters to attend to. Ides of October coming up. The Festival of Mars, don't you know.
Oh, yes, yes, of course.
Aurelia will look after you. Won't you, darling?
Yes, dear. If you will just excuse me too, Doctor, Evelyn, I will go and arrange some wine.
Oh, lovely. Thank you. (sotto) I don't think the queen is very pleased to see us.
in the near distance
What do you think you're doing, inviting them here?
Aurelia, darling.
If you want a son and heir, you are going to have to
both leave earshot
I have an idea she had a rather different sort of evening planned. Don't you see? It's October.
Yes?
And nine months after October is
July! Of course. Not that it would be called July now. It was named after Julius Caesar as it was the month in (penny drops) which he was born. Ah. Now I think I may be thinking what you're thinking.
I'm all for being present while history's being made, but I think this is a bit too close.
Perhaps it would be as well if we left. Come on, while they're both out of the room.
Tardis door opens.
There. From the Tiber to the Tardis.
From the sublime to the ridiculous.
Tardis door closes.
Really? Well, ignoring for the moment the slight on my beloved time-ship, I had the impression you weren't too taken with the glories that were Rome.
Well, it was smellier, noisier, and grottier than I'd expected. That doesn't matter really. Stepping into the pages of history, Earth's history, that's always special to me.
I know.
Just think. In nine months time, the first ever Caesarian section will take place, and out will pop baby Julius.
Ah. That's a myth, I'm afraid
Is it? I thought the procedure was named after him.
Oh, that's widely believed, but Aurelia survived the birth, and sad to say, that would not have been the case had she gone a Roman surgeon's knife.
Oh.
Now, where to next?
Under a Roman surgeon's knife.
Mmm hmm?
I mean, what if that's it?
What if what's what?
What if that's how Aurelia survived? Perhaps she wasn't attended by a Roman surgeon. Perhaps it was a Doctor, from the future.
Are you suggesting I deliver Julius Caesar?
Yes.
No! Evelyn, it's hardly my area of expertise.
But you know things. You can give people a nudge in the right direction. Can we really afford to ignore the possibility that hopping forward nine months might save a life?
Oh, very well. Forward nine months.
The Tardis dematerialises.
It's a bit chilly for July. I should have brought a cardie.

Oh, Evelyn, Evelyn. For a historian, sometimes your ignorance astounds me. Before Caesar reformed the calendar, the months were all over the place. No two years in a row contained the same number of days. Anyway, the walk should have warmed you up.
Yes, about that. Would it have been so terrible to land just a little bit closer to the Caesar's house? My poor knees.
These sort hops are tricky affairs, you know. To arrive in the same spot exactly nine months later is an exceptional feat of piloting.
If you do say so yourself.
Anyway, we're here now. Hope they remember us.
I hope they don''t.
Knock on door.
[OC]: All right, all right!
Door opens.
Yes?
Oh, hello. I'm the Doctor and this is Evelyn
Aurelia screaming with labour pains.
This isn't a good time.
Thing's aren't going well. I knew it. Come on, Doctor.
Hey!
Excuse me.
A baby cries.
Don't panic, help's here.
Out of my way.
Oh, Doctor, is it supposed to look like that?
Doctor? Is everything all right?
Oh, er, it seems to be, yes.
No thanks to you. What do you mean by barging in like this?
You said Aurelia was having a bad time.
No, I said this wasn't a good time. For a visit. And it isn't. At least make yourself useful. You there, pass me that knife. I need to cut the cord. Hurry up, man.
Oh, I'm sorry. Were you addressing me? A knife, did you say?
Oh, don't worry, I'll get it myself.
Er, this one? Here you are. Ow!
Look what you're doing.
Doctor, you cut yourself.
Oh, I'm all right.
As it Aurelia, it seems. I was wrong. We weren't needed.
No hand of fate on our shoulders after all.
It's actually nice for a change, expecting things to be going wrong and they're not. It's usually the other way round. This time absolutely everything's gone right.
Thank you. Oh, my darling.
Congratulations, Aurelia. You have a beautiful baby girl.
Girl?
She shall be called Julia.
Julia Caesar?
(breathless) Doctor, slow down.
No time to dawdle, Evelyn. We're nearly back at the Tardis.
This is bad, isn't it? We've changed history.
I fear so.
Nine months ago there's Aurelia all well, you Know, please to see her husband, and then we turn up, so she's not happy, and there's no son and heir conceived that night. By the time she actually
does get pregnant, nature's decided to arrange things with two X chromosomes instead.
Exactly. We must find a way of reversing the damage, and quickly. Oh, here we are.
Unlocks Tardis door.
If we go back to the very moment things went wrong.
Another tricky short hop.
No, I just press the fast return switch, like so, and we're snapped back to where we came from as if we're on a piece of elastic.
Talking of which, let's put some Elastoplast on that cut.
Oh no, I don't think that's necessary.
Oh yes, it is. And some antiseptic, unless you want to get blood poisoning. Here, I've got some in my handbag. There you go.
Ow! Ooo! That stings.
Don't be a baby. And talking of babies.
Yes, the great Caesar, a girl. We have to return to Julius and Aurelia and make sure er love is in the air.
I suppose so. Hang on a minute.
Yes?
What did you mean by that? The great Caesar, a girl. Are you saying a woman couldn't be great?
Oh, of course not. But this is ancient Rome. Women aren't even allowed to hold office.
And that's the problem.
What?
Imagine how much better the world would be if the most important Roman of all time were female! It could be the catalyst that changes all of history.
Exactly! That's what we're trying to stop.
But it will be a change for the better.
Causality unravelling is hardly for the better.
Perhaps we were meant to do this.
Oh, as we were meant to intervene in Aurelia's childbirth? The only thing we achieved there was to scare the poor woman half to death by asking if her baby was supposed to look like that.
Well, it was a bit of a shock. I'd never seen a newborn before. I never had children, you see.
Oh, Evelyn.
I never will have children now. My family tree stops here. Nothing of me going on into the future.
Now don't
I suppose it just wasn't my destiny to have children. But travelling with you is.
Hmm? I'm not sure I follow you.
And perhaps I'm here with you for a reason.
Evelyn, I think you're getting a little overwrought.

Can you honestly tell me that baby girl isn't meant to be born, and that our interference isn't an important part of history? What about Mozart? You remember that. Before we became involved, he was only remembered for lift music and film soundtracks.
I don't think this is the same thing.

But you don't know for sure, do you? I may not have had a child of my own, but I'm going to make sure that baby girl is born. Nothing of me going on into the future, but at least the future will be better if women are in charge. No wars, no poverty, no size zero models.
No! I'm sorry. A diverted timeline could lead to anything. We have to put Time back on the right track.
No, we don't! I won't let you. This is too important.
Yes, it is. You go and put the kettle on. We'll discuss it over a cuppa. I'll just check the atmospheric conditions outside.
Tardis door opens.
All right, I'll er
Tardis door closes.
Doctor!
[OC]: I'm sorry, Evelyn. I can't let you out here.
Doctor, come back here! Let me out! Doctor!
[OC] They've gone now, darling.
[OC]: I'm hardly in the mood.
[OC]: Aurelia, my love, they said they were old friends.
[OC]: Well, they weren't.
Here we are. (knocks on door.) Hello?
Door opens.
Doctor, I thought you had left. Aurelia, my dear, it's the Doctor.
What? Oh, Doctor. What a surprise.
Well, it was rude to leave without saying goodbye. Evelyn felt a bit off-colour.
But we still have the pleasure of your company.
I hope it will be a pleasure. You see, I couldn't help noticing that our presence caused a little, oh, tension, shall we say?
Oh, no, no, my dear Doctor.
Oh yes, yes, yes. No need to be polite. I wanted to make it up to you. May I come in?
Oh, er, oh, of course.
walking
Here, come and sit down. There, that's it. Now then, let me pour you a cup of wine. There.
Oh, thank you.
Thank you.
Now, if music be the food of love, perhaps you will allow me to play you a bite to eat.
Plays Greensleeves on a lute or a cithara.
(sighs) Oh darling, I'm sorry I was cross.
That's all right, my love.
It's just that I wanted
interrupted by 'music' on comb and tissue paper
What's that?
Evelyn!
The front door was open. Hope you don't mind. You shouldn't have left the Tardis manual lying around. I worked out how to override the lock. (plays On Ilkley Moor Bah Tat)
Evelyn, stop that this minute!
Sorry. Have I spoilt the moment?
Please excuse us. Come along, Evelyn.
I am trying to stop the Web of Time from unravelling and possibly destroying the entire world.
And I am trying to make the world a better place.

Evelyn, it's not like an old pullover. You can't just get a pair of needles and reknit the unravelled timeline in to something that's a better fit. Now, are you going to sit quietly and make polite conversation, or shall I take you back to the Tardis, jump forward sixty years, and tell Nero that you're a Christian, and aren't his lions looking hungry?
All right, all right. I'll make polite conversation.
Good.
Ah, this is nice.
Very nice.
Charming. Really, the Doctor had no need to prepare dinner himself. We may not live in the best part of town, but we do have slaves.
Oh, don't worry. He enjoys it. He's quite a dab hand in the kitchen. Have you ever heard of Typhoid Mary?
No.
No, I suppose you wouldn't have. She was a cook who didn't realise she had typhoid fever. Everyone who ate her food. Don't know why she sprang to mind. Forget I mentioned it. You just enjoy the meal.
Evelyn, are you saying the Doctor
Ah, Julius, Aurelia, all ready for a delicious dinner a deux, I hope?
You and Evelyn won't be joining us?

Well, two's company, they say. Now I did say that music was the food of love, but I think you'll find that another food of love is er food. (laughs) To start, a dish of asparagus, lightly steamed and drizzled with olive oil.
Thank you.
Ooo, that's lovely.
Delicious.
Well done, Doctor.
Thank you, Evelyn.
Yes, I'm glad you're enjoying it. Me, I never can eat asparagus. It's something of a diuretic, you know. Makes you go.
Ahem.
And perhaps I shouldn't mention it in polite company, but we're all friends here. I don't know if you've noticed, but it causes a smell.
Evelyn, let the nice people enjoy their meal.
That's all right. I've had enough.
Er, yes, so have I.
Ah, well. Oh, never mind. Time for the second course. This you will enjoy. The secret ingredient is slivers of truffle, one of the greatest delicacies known to man.
And pig. Especially the amorous pig.
What do you mean?

Well, it's an interesting fact. The reason that pigs are so good at hunting out truffles is that the truffle, that thing that you have on your plate there, contains a chemical which mimics the reproductive hormones of swine.
Oh, really.
Oh yes.
Thank you for that titbit, Evelyn. Perhaps we'll just skip straight to dessert. Strawberries. Evelyn, before I serve, do you have anything to say on the bodily effects of eating strawberries?
No, no, no. Nothing at all.
And what about the chemical secreted by the strawberry?
Er, no, don't think so.
Does the strawberry have any intrinsic properties whatsoever that lead you to believe it is an unsuitable ingredient for a romantic dinner?
No.
Good. There you go.
Not intrinsic properties. (The Doctor groans) But of course it grown in manure.
Right, that's it! Julius, Aurelia, please excuse us. Evelyn, you are leaving now.
Yes, of course.
Hey, no. What?
Evelyn.
I was making polite conversation.
You were deliberately sabotaging my every effort.
Oh, aphrodisiacs don't work anyway.
Well, they certainly won't now. Come on, you are going back to the Tardis, and you are going to stay there.
Doctor!
No arguments. You, Doctor Smythe, are on Tardis arrest until this timeline is back on track.
At least let me walk under my own steam. You're going far too fast. My poor knees.
You can put your feet up when you're safely back in the Tardis.
No, no, I mean it. I have to sit down. Now. Oh!
Oh. Over here, on the edge of this fountain. All right?
I, I think so. A rest and a couple of my pills, and I'll be. Oh.
What?
My pills. They're in my handbag. I must have left it in the control room when I got out the antiseptic.
Well, the Tardis isn't far.
Oh, no. I can't walk any further. Doctor, please.
Yes, I'll fetch it.
I think it's under the console.
All right, I won't be long. You, you just sit here and rest.
Yes. Yes, I will. Thank you, Doctor.
Back in a minute, Evelyn. (leaves)
Right, sit here and rest? I don't think so. Julia Caesar, you will exist, whether the Doctor likes it or not.
Right, now it's my turn.
Knocks on door. Door opens.
Doctor! How did you get here before me?
(breathless) Evelyn Smythe.
Yes?
Evelyn Smythe, I have come from the future.
I know. So have I.
I mean your own personal future. I have brought a message from your future self.
Oh? Why couldn't I come myself?

The dangers of crossing your own timeline are too great. But not as great as the dangers that will occur if you do not stop this course of action now. Evelyn, I come from a future where the world is doomed, thanks to your meddling.
Oh!

The air is aflame, the seas have boiled dry. No creature can live on the Earth. And as we watched the death throes of your planet, for every single second of every day of every moribund week, your future self felt nothing but regret. If only I could stop myself, she would say. I would do anything to be able to prevent myself from ruining the Doctor's brilliant plan.
Oh goodness, I. Hang on. If you've been hanging around dying Earth for weeks, how come you've still got that bit of plaster on your finger? Let me look.
Ow!
That cut's still fresh. And you were out of breath from running to get here before me. You're just trying to fool me!

Fool you? How about oh Doctor my knees, I can't walk. Did you really think I'd just leave you on your own after your last performance? And that was a low blow, Evelyn, pretending to be in pain. You think I don't worry about you?
It was a means to an end.
A means to the end of the world. A world I am trying to save.
No! You're trying to perpetuate a patriarchal society. Which, I suppose, is something I should expect from someone whose race calls themselves the Time Lords.
Oh, yes, yes. Well, in Gallifreyan the emphasis is rather
What is all this noise? Ah, Evelyn, Doctor.
I might have guessed.
I'm sorry. We
A baby cries.
Now you've woken up the baby. Slave, see to Julia this instant.
The baby?
Julia?
Yes, our younger daughter, Julia.
You should know, you were there when she was born. It was only nine months ago. You can't have forgotten.
Nine months ago?
Yes. I certainly won't forget. Barging in without a by your leave. And the things you said.
So you actually did recognise us tonight. You weren't just being polite.
Polite? I nearly bit my tongue in half not saying the things I wanted to say.
Then I shall say them for you, my love. Had I realised that these two were the very ones who had trespassed at your child bed, I would never have allowed them in the house.
Ah, well, perhaps it is time for us to be going.
Yes, clear off before I have you flogged. And if I ever see you again
Oh, Julius, you're so manly.
I was only trying to help.
Doctor, I think your work here's done.
Ah, right. We'll be off, then.
Julius and Aurelia shut the door on them, laughing together.
So we were never in 100BC after all.
And we're not going there now. I think Caesar can manage to be born without us.
What a mess. We went nine months into the past by mistake. Doctor, for a Time Lord your ignorance sometimes astounds me. When you're in years BC, you count backwards.
The Tardis got confused.
The Tardis my foot.
Well, it's just automatic to add rather than take away when you're going into the future.
The future. I suppose it's safe?
Yes. Huh, it was never at risk.
Except from me. It would be better, you know, a world with women in charge.
Perhaps it would. But we both know that's not what this was all about, Evelyn. Look at everything we've done. Your bloodline may not go forward, but you are very definitely part of the future.

Yes, but what I realised just now in there is that that's not what children are about. Julia, she was always meant to be. History barely remembers her. Julius is the famous one, carrying on his father's name. But right now, at this moment, that doesn't matter, not to that little baby in there. If I had had a child, it wouldn't have been about me being part of the future, it would have been about my child being part of the present.
But you still have regrets?
About never giving life? Yes.
But you saved many lives, made many lives better.
You know what I'd really like right now? A hot pie.
As long as it's not asparagus?
Or truffle.
Flamingo tongues used to be considered a delicacy.
Oh, poor flamingoes.
And peacock brains.
Oh. Perhaps a pie wasn't such a good idea. Now cake you can't go wrong with.
At Roman weddings, a cake was broken over the bride's head to ensure fertility.
My Own Private Wolfgang by Robert Shearman
Dr Who theme played on a harpsichord.
You're not going to finish it like that, are you?
No, no, just taking a breather.
I was going to say it seemed a bit abrupt.
This is all such rubbish.
Oh, I wouldn't say that, sir. I was rather enjoying it.
Really?
Mmm, yes. I especially like the diddly dum bit in the middle.
It's not the Magic Flute, though, is it? Hardly a requiem.
Well, no, sir. But then your Requiem is your masterpiece. Nothing's ever going to touch your Requiem. This er thing has charms all of its own.
I should just burn it. That's what I'd do if I had any integrity.
This is just nerves talking, sir. Tonight's performance preying on your mind?
Who are all these people you've invited?
Just friends, sir. Nothing to worry about.
I don't have any friends. Only you, just you. All these years. God, look what I've been reduced to, all pally with the hired help.
Now you're getting all sentimental, sir, and that won't do at all. Save sentiment for music, sir. It's less embarrassing there.
You're quite right. Of course.
And you must finish composing. In a few hours, your guests will arrive, all expecting your new symphony. I really wouldn't end it so abruptly. No one likes things that sound unfinished.
Just tell me it's going to be all right.
It's going to be all right, hmm? What could possibly go wrong?
Just a moment. We're here to see Mozart?
Is that a problem?
Well, it's just that when you promised me a concert, I thought we'd be hearing something good.
Oh, Mozart's all right. Some of the tracks on his Greatest Hits CD are really rather nice.

I didn't even think there really was a Mozart, not really, after so many hundreds of years. No one can live that long. I just thought it was a name musicians used to hide behind, when they didn't want to own up to having written anything really, really, bad.
I used to think that. By the time he was producing his ten thousandth symphony, I thought there could be no other explanation. And yet, here we are. Exciting, isn't it? Oh, I do enjoy getting a
mystery to solve.
Mmm, so do I. I just rather hoped there'd be a nice musical accompaniment. So, can't win em all. Oh!
Now what's wrong?
My mask. It's chafing my nose.
Leave it. This is a masked ball. The invitation says Mozart's 100th birthday party. concert and nibbles, bring you own mask.
Oh, that's just great. My nose is itching and I'm going to have to listen to Mozart, and the last thing I heard of his was that soundtrack for the remake of The Italian Job.

I admit by your time, his stuff had gone off the boil somewhat. For me, nothing was ever the same once he started using electronic drum kits. Once you've heard one ambient concept album, you've heard them all.
Gentlemen, may I interest you in a fruit scone?
Oh, not for me. I've already eaten.
Oh, please. Mister Mozart was very particular everyone try the scones. He made them himself.
Oh, thank you.
Thank you.
Oh, just a second. Is that a woman behind that mask?
Hello?
But you can't be. I mean, it's quite impossible.
Clearly not.
Forgive me. Madam, I was just. Can I ask where you got your invitations?
Certainly. My spaceship intercepted them in the Time Vortex.
I see. That really shouldn't have happened.
You don't seem very surprised.
Of course I'm surprised, madam. I'm from 1856. What would I know of Time Vortexes. Let's not confused the well-trained reserve of a butler for anything anachronistic. If you will excuse me.
leaves
Funny sort of butler. How's the scone?
All right. Bit too much sugar. I'll put it in my pocket for later.

If I could have your attention, please, gentlemen. You know him. You love him. And it's his hundredth birthday. So let's put our hands together and be upstanding for the outstanding Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart!
Cheers and applause.
Happy birthday!
Happy birthday!

Thank you. No more. Thank you, my friends. Are you my friends? It's hard to tell beneath those masks. A man must consider himself fortunate indeed to have so many, especially when I was pretty sure I had no friends whatsoever, which does rather beg the question, who are you lot and why are you here? To see me, who at the age of 6 played for all the crowned heads of Europe, now at a hundred playing to a bunch of strangers with their faces covered. Still, that's life. But thanks for coming anyway, to witness what I hope will be my greatest performance. You know, I used to be asked, Mozart, they said, what makes great art? And I never really knew. I used to say some guff about a gift from God, but deep down I was just relieved I could do it. No one asks me now, of course, which is a shame, because I now have the answer. I'll tell you, great art is just a matter of knowing when to stop. That's it. It's as simple as that. I have some music to play you. Oh, it's not very good. Oh, the notes are all right, nothing's discordant, but it has no point to it, no soul. I've nothing to say any more. It's just pretty noise. I've had nothing to say for years, and I look back and I wish I'd died young, before I realised I was just another mediocrity. It's time to stop. This is my performance.
Click of gun being cocked. Gasps.
Now sir, put the gun down.
Don't fret, my friend. The end of this symphony is long overdue.
Bang!
No!
Oh, it hasn't worked. It hasn't worked. (bang! bang!) What a failure I am. I can't even kill myself properly. Get out of my way.
Door opens and closes.
Well, I'm sure you'll want to thank er Mister Mozart for his new avant-garde composition, which he calls Concerto with Firearm. Do enjoy the refreshments. I'm sorry, sir, you can't go in there.
These are Mister Mozart's private quarters.
This is no time to stand on etiquette. The man's just shot himself.
Three times, and in the head.
I'm a doctor. I can help.
If my master needs help, sir, then I am the one to provide it.
However proficient in butlering you may be, unless you're also a qualified oh!
Please stand back.
Gun being cocked.
I would truly regret having to use this gun on you.
There's no need for this.

I don't think a well-bred butler like you wants to disturb this party any further, do you? Now, I'm going to open that door, and my friend is coming with me. If you decide to shoot us, that's up to you.
Ah, I do wish you hadn't said that, sir.
So dol.
And why is that?

Because, of course, I couldn't shoot you, a well-bred butler like myself. Very well, then. If waggling a revolver at you really won't suffice, you'd better come with me. (sotto) But please be sensitive. Mister Mozart does hate meeting his public.
Door opens.
After you, Evelyn.
Door opens.
Oh, Butler, that didn't go well at all. Who the Devil are these people?
I'm sorry, sir. The Doctor insisted.
I don't need a doctor. I need the exact opposite of a doctor.
How are you feeling?
How do you think? I just fired three bullets into my temple and I'm still here, so rather sore, more than a little disappointed.
I wish you'd discussed this with me beforehand.
You'd only have talked me out of it. Well, that's that. Stepping (sic) won't work, hanging won't work, nor will bullets. I am stuck here.
But why kill yourself in the first place?
Wait a moment. Hang on.
Three bullets clatter onto the floor.
That's impossible!
Oh, my body heals very quickly. Apparently even spits out the bullets all by itself. What time is it, Butler?
Your visitor will be here soon, sir.
Damn. I was really rather hoping I'd be dead by then.
I shall inform you when he arrives. (leaves)
Who's coming? What's going on?

I don't know his name. Years ago, when I was young, he came to me. I was dying at the time, I'm sure of it. I was coughing blood. I knew it was the end, and this man appeared from nowhere wearing a black mask. He told me he could save my life, I could live for ever, on condition that on every birthday he would find me and I'd have a new symphony to show him.
I can quite see why you'd be tempted.
It was a trap, Doctor. All I wanted was to go on producing music, to change the world my way with operas and concertos, and so much beauty. I thought my inspiration would never run dry.
Some would say, I don't know, with a long life ahead of you, why not just try something else?
Oh, I have. Pottery, poetry, pastry making. Did you try my scones?
Mmm. They were all right.

Oh, I can make cheesy twists, petit four. They're quite tricky. But there's a bakers down the road makes them even better. If you have a genius for something, it's very hard to put up with being just all right at something else. If only I hadn't signed his contract, by now I'd be dead, but I'd be a dead somebody.
And he's coming here, now? Tell him you've changed your mind.
Yes, I can really see the Devil buying that.
You think he's the Devil?

Well, black mask, offers of eternal life? It's all a bit devilish, wouldn't you say? He appears out of thin air, reads my music, has a chuckle, then takes off again. If I wasn't so terrified, I'd find it more than a little rude.
Door opens.
Sir, your guest has arrived.
Then I shall go and greet him.
You know, I'd rather like to see this masked man of yours.
He says he'll only talk to Mister Mozart.
Well, Mister Mozart has a headache. Bullets can do that sort of thing.
Exactly. Take us to him.
It's worth a try. What's the worst he can do, make me immortal again, hmm?
Door opens.
He's in here, sir. Be careful.
Door closes.
Hello there. Now, Mister Mozart thinks you're the Devil. Are you really? Or are you, as I suspect, just some nineteenth century equivalent of a time-share salesman.
(slightly muffled) Leave me. I will speak only to Mozart.
Mozart is otherwise indisposed.
That's right. And as his legal representative, I need to point out some problem with this contract of yours.
There is nothing wrong with the contract.
Article 37 subsection 3. No contract binding if either party does business behind a mysterious mask. It's a standard clause. Which leads me to wonder, who is it that's hiding behind there?
Let's get this mask off.
Keep away from me.
There!
No. You? How can it be you?
What do we do?
Evelyn, no. Keep away from him! Argh! Evelyn! Oh, they've vanished. Where's she gone? Where have you taken her?
I've not taken her anywhere, sir. I'm standing right in front of you.
Oh, but you have. That man in the mask was you. You can't deny it.
I'm as surprised as you are, sir. If, as a butler, I wasn't so adept at reining in my feelings, I assure you I'd be gawping.
I've had enough of this. My friend is in danger. I'm in no mood for secrets. Who are you?
I'm Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
Let me go!
(normal voice) Steady. These time travel hops can make you a bit giddy.
Why have you kidnapped me?
I haven't. I don't want you. Not my fault if you got too close to the warp field, is it?
Take me back to the Doctor.
Only wish I could, but I only get so many time travelling privileges a week. I'm a working man. Only get Sundays off.
Where are we? It's like an enormous kitchen.
Well, that's because it is an enormous kitchen, and as you can see, I've got an enormous amount of washing up to do. I'd best get started.
Just tell me what's going on.
You give me a hand with these dishes, I'll tell you whatever you like. Here, some rubber gloves. Catch. Now, what do you prefer, cleaning or drying?
I've heard about artists being self-obsessed, but surely employing yourself as your butler is taking things a bit far?
Oh please, keep it to yourself, sir. I'd hate the master to find out.
You're telling me he doesn't know?

You've no idea what he can be like, poor chap. He has no friends, no family any more, only his music. And that's been scraping the bottom of the barrel since the early 1800s. He'd have no reason to get out of bed, no reason to open his eyes. If it weren't for me, his loyal servant, his trusted
companion
Who just happens to be him.
Well, quite. Imagine how he'd feel if he knew the only person who gave a damn about him was in fact him. Talk about a let-down.
And that's what you 're doing here, is it? You're here to make yourself feel better about yourself?

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart will live forever. His music may fade away into obscurity, but the man himself can never die. He needs someone to care. Who better than me? At least I understand him. So I travelled back in time to pledge myself to him, protect him, for always.
Back in time? So where does a time-travelling Mozart actually come from then?
You see, Mozart was once considered the greatest composer who ever lived.
I've heard his Eurovision entries. Find that a little hard to believe.

Oh no, no. He was wonderful. History once knew him as this wonder child, composing operas at the age of ten. And before I popped along and interrupted things, he died in 1791, his masterpiece, his Requiem, completed by his bedside. The world thought they'd been robbed of one of their greatest geniuses. This was sublime music, Evelyn. Music that made you realise there was no limit to what man could achieve. Pass the sponge.
Oh, right. Here.
So really, you could hardly blame them for what they did.
Blame whom? What happened?

Thousands upon thousands of years later, when cloning was child's play, they went back to Salzburg, to Vienna, rifled through the houses where Mozart had once lived, scraped the very fingerprints from his long-rusted harpsichords, and from the DNA created him anew.
And that's you?
Me and my brothers. The Mozart model's a big seller.
What?

Oh, just imagine it. Every home with a Mozart of its own, nice and trim and consumer-friendly, with a German accent smoothed out, play arias, whistle symphonies, all on tap whenever you want it. And of course, do the washing-up, the ironing, do the supermarket run.
That's terrible!
They've even got me babysitting. I wouldn't mind, but they're always screaming, you know? I never know how to shut them up.
How many of you Mozarts are there?
Oh, at a rough guess, eight hundred thousand.
What? You must be joking.

Oh, there would be more, but you know the Mozart is very expensive. We come with a lifetime guarantee, we put self-regenerating fluid in our blood just in case of accidents, and that stuff doesn't come cheap.
So why aren't you with your owners now?

Oh, they threw me out. I, I don't know what happened. Mozart wasn't so fashionable any more, or something? Lots of us suddenly out on the streets, nowhere to go. I begged enough money to get one time-travel trip, came straight here.
And what of those other Mozarts without anywhere to live?
That's why I wanted this concert, sent invitations through Time, told them they had to be here, just to show them why they'd been created. Give my brothers some little meaning.
What, the audience? Wait a moment. You mean
Door opens.

That one there, with the champagne? That's a Mozart whose owners kept him in a kennel. I ask you. A kennel. That one by the stairs? They worked him day and night without any sleep till he just collapsed, and they threw him out with the rubbish. Even that little kid there, you see?
Mmm hmm.
That's Mozart as a twelve year old. The deluxe children's model.
Is there anyone in this house who isn't Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart?
I thought if I could just change history, go back, kill Mozart as a baby, something like that. But you know, that seemed very unfair on Mozart.
Well, it is a bit.
But then I realised, only the good die young. The mediocre just stick around for ever. If I saved

his life, if he kept on composing more and more until the world was sick of it, then no one would want clones of him. No one would bother with his fingerprints in the first place, and I'd never be made.
It's a rather convoluted way to kill yourself, isn't it?

I don't want death, Evelyn. I want oblivion. I popped back to 1791, pumped Mozart full of self- regenerating fluid, it cleared his tuberculosis no end, and I told him to set to work on some new music. Have you heard some of his latest stuff? Oh, it's rubbish.
What you've done to him, it's terrible. How can you recommend to posterity like that?
Oh, he was only too eager. I'd never want to hurt him. I like the man. Well, I would. He's very like me. He gets to go on living, I get to never get born. This way everybody's happy.
But Mozart isn't happy. He shot himself.
Oh, it was probably an accident.
Three times?
Oh, he was just messing around.
In the head?
Ah. No, that doesn't sound like the actions of a happy man, no.

Write yourself out of history if you want to. If you don't want to contribute anything to this funny merry-go-round, that's up to you. When someone so obviously strives to rise above the rest to make some sort of difference, and when that man is you, how can you bear to stop that? How can you do that to yourself? And I'm not drying this saucepan, either. There's still marks all over it. Look.
The Tardis materialises.
A blue box, appearing out of nowhere.
The Tardis door opens.
And now a man in fancy dress getting out of it. Oh yes, Wolfgang, old fellow. You're definitely dying.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. The one and only.
I once saw my Piano Concerto in C Major played with nothing more than a harmonica and a tin whistle. I thought I'd seen everything, but this takes the biscuit.
I'm here on urgent business. A matter of life and death. Well, yours, I'm afraid.
Oh dear.
You've no reason to believe a word I say, but here's someone you should recognise.
Hello, sir.
Good Lord, it's me, isn't it?
This must be confusing for you, sir, but please listen carefully. Any moment now, a man will arrive. You mustn't believe a word he says.
I see. And how will I know this man?
Oh, you'll know him. It'll be you.
Me?
That's right.
So aman who's me is telling me that I mustn't trust another man who's me.
Yes.
Well done, sir.
Well, I'm glad that's clear, then.
Whoosh!
Doctor.
Evelyn. Oh, are you all right.
Oh, we found you at last. Back in 1856 he said you'd be here.
This is the man I was talking about. Mister Mozart, you mustn't listen to him.
Hello. I Know this must seem very odd.
Heaven help me. It's me again.
No, please, believe me, I wish you no harm. Evelyn has shown me I was wrong. I've come to help.
Doctor, I've spent the last week washing up. He's right. We must do something to help him. No one should have to scrub away at that much grease.
I'm just relieved I'm here in time. Mister Mozart, another man is coming. You mustn't trust him, or believe a word he says.
I get the idea. And who is this man?
Well, that's where it gets confusing.
It's an earlier version of me.
Right. And I'm you, right?
In a manner of speaking.
But wait a moment. This version of me told me not to believe what this version of me says, so
No, sir. I was wrong. You can believe what this version says.
Oh, that's good.
It'll be another me you have to watch out for. I mean you. I mean us.
Yes, yes. You know, all this is making me very peckish. Has anyone got anything to eat?
Ah, er, oh, er, here. It's a scone I made a start on.
Thanks.
But I only nibbled round the edges.
I hope you like it, sir. You made it yourself.
Of course, I don't expect you to believe me. Not after what I've done. So someone you can trust is following on behind me.
So long as you don't mean
Whoosh!
You there. Yes, you in the bed.
He did.
I have a bone to pick with you.
Oh dear, I look horribly old.
A hundred years today. What have you been playing at, you young whipper-snapper? How dare you muck around with my life like this?
Well, it's my life, I'd have thought.

No, trust me. After the arthritis, oh, and the rheumatism, and living through that rainy spell in the 1830s, I very much earned it. Don't you even think about signing anything which elongates our life. I am telling you, it's not worth it. So, when a man pops up in a mask, don't believe a word he says.
And I am guessing that underneath this mask it'll be
You, yes.
I wish I had something stronger than this scone.
He's taking a while to get here.
Whoosh!
Oh, good.

We know who you are and what you want.
The game's up, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

It's very odd, having identical versions of yourself pop up around your death bed. Pardon me for not rising. I'm a little incapacitated at the moment. Whether from tuberculosis or social awkwardness, I can't be sure.

Right, so let me just get this straight. Getting a bit confused. Could be the dying.
Of course.
This is the me I shouldn't trust.
Yes!
2: No! Listen to what I say, and you can compose your music forever.
I don't know, chaps. Sounds like a good deal to me

Wolfgang, at the moment you're the greatest composer who's ever lived. By the twenty eighth century, you'll be strictly for the bargain bin. Now, I know you don't know what a bargain bin is, but believe me, you will.
2: So much talent, so much to offer the world. How can you refuse?
Just a moment. This scone I am eating. You say I made this?
Yes, that's one of yours.
It's not very good, is it. It's far too sweet. And the pastry is all crumbly. Look.
The pastry is so hard to get right.
My future music, will it be like this pastry?
Oh, even worse, once you discover hip-hop.
Oh, that sounds quite ghastly. I'm sorry, masked version of me, but no deal.
2: What? No
I don't know if I'm on the way out. I rather suspect I am. But if I die, I die. And if I live, I'll make my music and my scones without your help.

The maestro has spoken.

Ah, but that's what you did to them. The way your owners got fed up with you all, treated you not like musicians but skivvies. And then all the unemployment, the homelessness, that was you. Only damaging Mozart's reputation, never ever destroying it.
2: So, how can I destroy it? Tell me! I'll make him use pan pipes if I have to.
Not even pan pipes can help you now. All the bad music you make Mozart right, there'll still be enough people to remember before Mozart jumped the shark.
2: You're saying they'll never stop cloning us and churning us out, not so long as he's got his masterpiece? While that exists, so will we?
And what is this masterpiece, exactly?
Oh, his Requiem.
Yes, the Requiem was very good.
I was always very proud of the Requiem.
I've only just finished it, you Know. Ever so relieved I got it done before I died. Nothing more ironic than an unfinished Requiem. Lots of lovely diminuendos. I like diminuendos.
Er, this Requiem of yours, where is it?
On the bedside table.
Ah, this is it here?
What are you doing?
Well, I wouldn't rob the world of Mozart's masterpiece, but maybe if it were just a little less masterly? Say we remove the last six or seven pages.
It's very good, you know. Better make it a dozen.

This way his genius will survive intact. There'll still be clones, because there'll always be fans, and fans never know when enough's enough, but maybe this way there won't be a demand for quite so many of them, and the ones that are made will be actually wanted as a result. Custom made, not mass produced.
That might just work.
I don't mind being a clone of an eighteenth century composer so long as I get a bit of respect.
Mozart's Unfinished Requiem. I like the sound of it.
Do you really think that just chopping off the end will be enough to damage Mozart's reputation?
I don't see why not. No one likes something that comes to an abrupt e
Bedtime Story by Joseph Lister
A clock ticks slowly.

Time to sleep now. Maybe time for just one story, hmm? Sleeping Beauty? (laughs) No, I think it's time I told you about the Doctor. I mean, if it weren't for him, we wouldn't be here at all, you and me. No, wouldn't be here at all. It started just after my father's first funeral. We'd all gone back to my mother's house. Dog-eared sandwiches, flaky sausage rolls, and memories of good old Frank Williams. Oh, you remember my mother, don't you?
Doctor Singh, but it weren't the same one I saw about my eyes. No, this were a different one.
Oh, she did like to talk, my mother, whether it were about the NHS or bin charges or school dinners.
Well I'm sorry, but I used to love pink custard, and I just don't see what it's got to do with Jamie Oliver.
And so that's where we were. Me, Aunt Julia, Uncle Patrick, my fiance Talia, and the baby. Mine and Talia's baby, sleeping in my old room.
And it's got a petrol station which is wonderful, because you can get points for
Talia, is it really wrong to be bored at me own Dad's funeral?
Shh. I'm dying to hear more about the new supermarket in Harrogate.
Love of God. It's okay, I've told her again we're not staying tonight. Last train's at 2310.
So, Patrick, are you and Julia going to stay over. My son can't, unfortunately. He's got to take the baby and his girlfriend
Fiance, Mum.
His fiance back to London. That's where he lives now. I told you he runs his own company, didn't 1? Designing the internet. How's your Lizzie doing? Is she still waitressing?
Sorry, Mary. We'd love to stay, but we can't. Patrick's got to be up early tomorrow, don't you, Patrick?
Snoring.
Oh, that is a shame. How are things on the farm? Still all organic?
Will it ever end?
I don't really have a problem with doing my bit for the environment and everything, but I want my carrots to be clean.
Doorbell.
I'll get it.
Oh, don't leave me.
Door opens.
Good evening. You must be Jacob. Delighted to meet you. I'm the Doctor, and this is my friend
Doctor Smythe!
Hello. Oh, Jacob Williams! You remember me, then.
Of course I do. Come in.
I imagine my disappearance probably made me quite infamous.
I think it's more how quickly you used to down a pint of Guinness, but yeah, the disappearance helped.
And of course my excellent lecturing abilities.
Oh yeah, those as well. Best tutor I ever had.
I should hope so.
[OC]: Who is it, dear?
It's me er, sorry, but why are you here?
I read about your Dad, and I just had to come and say how sorry I was. He was a lovely man.
[OC]: Jacob?
Sorry, you'd best come though.
Thank you. Oh, Doctor?
Oh, you've remembered I'm here. Yes, Evelyn?
Best behaviour, please.
Yes, Evelyn.
Door opens.
And there's just one parking space left, and it's outside some oh, my eyes. Who are you?
I'm the Doctor, and this is my friend
This is me old history tutor, Mum, Doctor Evelyn Smythe.
The one who disappeared? I have to say, I thought you'd be younger. I thought you'd run off with one of the students.
I'm so sorry for your loss, Mrs Williams.
Well, these things happen, but you have to cope, for the kids.
So anyway, how'd you know Doctor Smythe?
Oh, we're friends. We're travelling together.
And what brought you to our little village? Do you know, they film Heartbeat just down the road.
No, really? We just stopped off at the delightful tea rooms down on Smithers Street. I do love a good scone.
I went out to get a paper and read about your father's death.
And so we came here to offer our condolences.
So you two, you're friends?
Oh, not like that, dear.
Like what?
He's far too old for me.
Oh. Old?

They were a strange pair, all right, my old history lecturer and her friend the Doctor. She'd disappeared, you see, when I were at Sheffield. Just overnight, gone. Actually, you look like you're going yourself. I'd best skip some of the story before you sail off to dreamland.
Well, she lived just opposite. She was one of those, you know, always cricking her neck
continues softly in background.
Your mother.
Sorry? What about her?
She doesn't seem too stricken by grief.
Oh, you noticed.
Well, neither do you.
I am. The thing is, well, we knew he was going to die. Me Mum'll be gone soon as well.
Oh. Oh, I am sorry. Is she ill?
Oh no, she's fine.
What?
The thing is, I've got a son. A baby boy.
Oh, where is he?
Asleep in the other room. We've a baby monitor thing set up so he'll be okay. Mum didn't want him in here, not today. She's terrified of him. Sandwich?
She's scared of her own grandson?
Well, he's the reason Dad's oh! (coughs) Why do they insist on putting cress in? Yes, sorry. He's the reason Dad's dead. It's okay, I don't expect you to understand. It's a family thing.
Let me get this straight, Jacob. You're saying that your father died because you had a son?
Circle of life, innit?
Jacob, what exactly do you mean? When do you think your Mum's going to die?
Probably this week sometime. It might even be tonight.
And that doesn't bother you? Put that down and look at me! Are you saying you don't care?
Course I care, but it's why, well, it's one of the reasons I want to go back to London tonight. We're not, well, we don't talk about it. If it happens, it happens.
And you're just going to let it happen.
What else can I do?
Let me help.
Well, look, if you're really that interested, I can show you more in me father's study. He'd been researching the family tree, goes all the way back to the 1600s.
That sounds like a good place to start. Evelyn! Oh, sorry, she's a bit deaf.
Yes, Doctor?
Jacob's going to show me his family tree. Do you want to come and have a look?
No, it's fine. I'll stay here with the girls. We've just brewed another pot of tea.
Fine. I'll be back soon.
They collect the bottles and the papers, you know. Well, I mean, she puts them out days before.

When you've accepted something, you sometimes just forget how strange it is. I'd always known that my parents would die as soon as I became a father. It'd happened in our family throughout history, and so on the day my son Paul was born, my father Frank died. The thing was, this Doctor, he had this ability of instantly making you question things.
It's just as I said. We travel together.
She seems older.
Well, it's been a while since you last saw her. Probably longer for her. Come on. Loading, loading.
Computer cranking up.
It's just all that drinking tea stuff and yes dear stuff. She used to be a right old party animal.
Oh, ha ha, did she indeed?
Just a bit.
Musical chime.
Ah. Now, what's the file called?
Here, I'll just, ah, there you go.
The Williams' Family Tree.
Meanwhile, back in the living room, the inevitable was happening.
I see cake. Oh, I love cake.

Or a chocolate thing.
Yeah, all right. I'm a heifer.
Oh, ha, ha, ha. Such wit, Talia. I can see why my son is so enamoured.
Mrs Williams, look, I'm sorry you don't think I'm good enough for Jacob, but the thing is
Not good enough? You're damn right there.
You don't even know me.
Er, cake, anyone?
I don't need to know you. You killed Frank.
Sorry?
Maybe I should
You just stay there, Doctor Smythe. It's a joy to have someone intelligent around. Someone, someone who isn't just a dirty little trollop from wherever you're from.
Oi! Who the Hell do you think you're talking to? And what do you mean, I killed Frank?
Patrick, wake up. It's all kicking off.
Snore.
Really, I think it would be best if everyone just calmed down. Perhaps some more tea?
Come on, what do you mean, I killed Frank? Don't be so stupid.
It's that baby, that child of yours. It's the reason Frank's dead.
Goodness, really? Perhaps we could just sit down quietly and
It's evil. That kid's evil.
You're clearly upset. I think I should go.
You think? Is that what you think? You should never have come, that way none of this (choke, gurgle)
Mrs Williams? Quick, get her some tea.
Mary? Mary, what is it?
(choking) Oh great, and now it's my turn, you little
Gurgle, gasp, thud, expires.
Mrs Williams?
The baby cries over the monitor.
I think we should er. Talia, go and see to Paul.
Mary? God, she's dead.
Go and see to your son.
Yes.
Julia, where's the phone? We should call an ambulance.
She's dead.
[OC]: Shh, shh, it's okay. Go to sleep. Your mummy's here. Yes, that's it
Door opens.
Don't all congratulate me at once, but I think I've worked out what's going on.
Doctor, it's Mary.
Oh, no. No, that's not fair!
Mum.

Right, everyone get back. Let me look at her.
She's dead. Oh Jacob, I am sorry.
Doctor?
No pulse, no heartbeat, nothing. But ah! No.
Doctor, are you all right?
She, she's not dead. She's not. There's something. There's no Time there. She's frozen. She's alive.
What do you mean? What are you talking about?
She's wrong. Your mother, she's. Her time hasn't come to an end, it's just been paused.
Doctor, I've never seen you like this.
Sorry, Evelyn, it's just, well, imagine how you'd feel if you met a zombie. Someone who was dead and alive. She's like that to me. There's no Time.
You're saying she's not dead?
No, Jacob, she isn't.
And me Dad?
Your Dad? Oh, has he been
Buried. Oh God, he's been buried.
But he's. You, what's your name?
Julia. I'm Mary's sister, from Barnsley.
Yeah, yeah, just your name will be fine. Is that large gentleman your husband?
Yes. Why?
Well, wake him up and the pair of you get to the church. Frank Williams is alive, and he could be fully aware of everything that's happening to him.
But, but he's been. He's in the ground. He's in a coffin.
So don't just stand there, go and get him out of it. This is worse than I thought.
[OC]: That's it, go to sleep, to sleep. JJ Oranges and lemons say the bells of Saint Clements. Jd
Doctor, what exactly is going on?

The family tree. Jacob's right. For hundreds of years, every time a boy is born the grandparents have died. Only as I've just discovered, they don't die. They're frozen in Time, and I suspect fully aware of everything that happens to them.
But there's been so, so many. Are you saying that
All of them buried alive, lying in the coffin, awake, presumably until their mind breaks.
Oh, my God. Dad.

Talia, is everything all right?
[OC]: Yeah, Paul's asleep.
No, Evelyn, this isn't an illness or an accident. This is premeditated. This is planned. Think about it. It's only when a grandson is born. What does a grandson mean, hmm? Jacob.
Well, er, the family name continues?

Hello? Hello?
You need to press the button, Doctor.
Oh. Talia, is everything all right? Hello?
You need to let go of the button, Doctor.

I haven't got time to be pressing and unpressing buttons.
Doctor.
