Okay. I'm coming, Talia. (leaves)
The poor boy.
Let's take a closer look at his mother. Ah, should be all right. This time I know what to expect.
Baby cries.
I'll make us some tea.
Thank you, Evelyn. Now. Oh, even her watch has stopped. Mary, I know you can hear me, and I don't want you to worry. I can help you. I'll put an end to this. Jacob, are you with Talia yet?
[OC]: Yes, Doctor.
Good. Now, I want everyone to think. Let's say Talia is right. Let's say whoever or whatever is doing this is doing it out of passion.
What do you mean?

Oh, come on, Evelyn. Firstly, whoever is doing this is consumed by hate. They could just kill their victims rather than this horror. Secondly, they're long-lived. They live longer than your average human, anyway. So, you're a long-lived creature possessed by a pure hatred of one family, and you want to see them suffer. So, what does that suggest to you? I'd say that you'd want to witness the results of your actions, see them suffer.
I don't understand.

Whoever it is has got close to the family. Whoever it is was here when Mary was attacked. Now think. Come on, Doctor, think. How could someone keep getting close to the family generation after generation without anyone noticing?
I, I don't know.
I do. They need to blend in, become part of the family, enjoy watching them live, and then revel in watching their grief.
Talia? She wasn't part of the family. Perhaps she got together with Jacob so she could
What, kill her own son? And don't you think Frank Williams might have noticed if she'd been there when is own father died?
Well, what then?
A shape-shifter. The creature has to be a shape-shifter. How else could they do it?
[OC]: You mean an, an alien? A shape-shifter? So it could be anyone.
Oh, he's quick, isn't he?
Doctor, you're getting irritable.
Of course I am. This is horrible. And whoever did it is here, among us.
Even if that is the case, there's no need to take it out on the boy. Here, drink some tea.
And of course, if they're here, it suggests how they commit the crime. A touch, a sting, or
Your tea, Doctor.
A poison. I'm right, aren't I?
Doctor?
Stay there, Jacob. You too, Talia. I'll deal with this.
Doctor, perhaps you should sit down. Have a piece of cake.
Where is she?
What do you mean?
Where is Evelyn Smythe? What have you done with her!
Oh, Evelyn's sleeping. You think you're so clever. She really doesn't like that aspect of you.

Even Jacob spotted it. All the talk of tea and cake, talking to the girls, no interest in the family tree. The real Evelyn would have worked most of this out herself. She wouldn't have stood there asking 'what is it, Doctor? She wouldn't have stood there flustering as Mary Williams lay dying at her feet. She's made of far stronger stuff.
Oh, isn't she lovely. I just nipped out to get a paper.
And that's when you replaced her.
That's when I gave her my magic potion, and sent her off to dreamland.
Then you came back to the tea room, told me about Frank's funeral, and insisted we came.
I had to pay my respects.
Where is Evelyn?
Sleeping, in a field.
Jacob, can you hear me?
[OC]: Yes.
Call the police. Tell them to search the fields nearest to Smithers Street. When they find Evelyn's body, tell them to bring it here.
[OC]: But what if they don't believe me?
Make them believe you.
Such a strange man. Such a good man, burning with intelligence, travelling in this time machine. You see, I know what Evelyn knows. How she sees you. Mmm, I'd love to taste your mind.
I'd love to know who you are.

I've sent Mary and Frank to sleep. I'll disappear, and then return for Jacob when his own son breeds. So yes, let me tell you a story. I was lost in the darkness for so many centuries. Then, years ago, I fell to this world. It was so primitive, so emotional, and I was drawn in like a moth toa flame. I was drawn in, and I met a man.
Tobias Williams, back in, oh what, 1695, 1696?

How clever of you. So clever. You're right. I took human form, and I fell in love. It was so alien to me, these feelings, this responsibility. You've never had that, have you, hmm? The responsibility of love. I loved Tobias, and we were to be wed, but then I made the mistake of telling him what I was, what he was really in love with, and he spurned me, Doctor. He spurned me. Do you know what he called me? Do you?
A witch.
You know your history. I was burning at the stake, feeling the fire burn my skin. But the burning inside, that was worse. The hatred burnt inside me. How could he do this to the one he loves?
He didn't understand.

He knew what he was doing. I escaped the fire. My true form cannot be destroyed by such a simple element. I escaped, and I swore to myself that he would never be happy. And I watched, I watched as he met someone else, as he fell in love with someone else so easily. It was so easy for him. So, a year later I took on the form of a humble maid, and one night I listened at a door as his new wife read to their son. Read him a bedtime story. Do you know what the story was?
This was in 1698?
[OC]: Sleeping Beauty? Sorry, I studied it in college.
Clever girl. And I knew then, as I listened at that door, I knew what my revenge would be.
A hundred years of sleep.
For Tobias. For all of them. For all his sons, and his grandsons, and all those descendants who should have belonged to me.
You poor creature.
Oh, such a good man.
You didn't just sentence the Williams family, you sentenced yourself. You say you fell in love? Can you even comprehend the evil that you've committed?
Oh, calm down, Doctor. Drink some tea.
How many have you sentenced to your sleep?

Hundreds. And the thing about revenge is, it's not much fun if you can't tell people about it. I've sat there in pubs and hotels and tea rooms. I've told my story to so many. But I can't have them telling anyone else, now can I? Just a couple of drops of my magic, and off they go. Sleeping like a baby. Sleeping for a hundred years. Sleeping, but aware, listening, watching as their families mourn over them. Trying to scream out, but they're silent.
You've become the personification of hatred.
And now its your turn to sleep. You've had your story. Time for beddie-byes, Doctor.
Just a minute, Missus.
What do you want, child?
Thing is, you got it wrong. You've messed up big time.
Talia, what are you doing?
I'm sorry, Jacob, but it's time for the truth. Your mum was right about me.
What are you talking about?
I am a dirty little trollop.
What?
I'm sorry, Jacob. I'm so sorry, but I cheated on you.
Baby cries.
It's okay, Paul. Shh. Shh.
What? What do you? Talia, no.
Paul isn't yours. You remember that guy at college, the one you didn't like?
Paul's not mine?
Please, forgive me.
You tell me now? Me Mum and me Dad are gone, and now you tell me he's not, he's not mine. No!
What are you doing, boy? Get away from me!
Give me that. Is this what you wanted? Your revenge? Well, perhaps a nice cup of tea will help me. (coughs)
Jacob!
I can't deal with this. I can't cope with it. I loved (chokes, thud.)
Jacob?
The last of the family.
What?
Your story has ended.
No. No, it can't.
It has. You made a mistake. The whole family are now at peace. Sleeping, just as you wanted.
No!
Yes. So, what have you got to live for now, hmm? You're consumed by hate. You became hate. Whatever you were before, that's been lost. Your entire existence became about revenge, and now that's over.
No! (gurgles) No!
Just do us all a favour and go!
Noooo!
Transforms and fades away.
The end of the story.
Er, Doctor?
Yes?
Please tell me you Knew what we were doing?
I'm hoping you knew what I was doing.
Getting her to tell us what she was all about so we could stop her.
You were very good, you know. You almost had me convinced.
Oi, I'd never cheat on Jacob.
I know, I know.
So you can save them, yeah?
I can't bring them back. I don't know what the creature used. But I can take them away.
In your time machine.
That's right. Show them the universe for a hundred years. Give them sweet dreams.
Then bring them back.
It'll be like they've never been away.
(crying) And then it'll all be over?
The Tardis dematerialises.

He took me, my Mum, my Dad, Evelyn. He took our sleeping bodies into his magic box and he showed us everything. He gave us the sweetest dreams. You should have seen it. So much out there in the stars. And then, after a hundred years, we woke up. We woke up and he brought us back to that very same day, that same moment. And off they went, the Doctor and Evelyn, back to their adventures, and we stayed behind and all lived happily ever after, didn't we, Jacob? Did you really think the Doctor could fool me, after all I Knew about him from Evelyn? Oh, your fiance's lies about your son being illegitimate couldn't harm me any more than the flames of the stake. You all thought you were so clever, just because the Doctor was there. You thought I'd died, but I didn't die, I just reverted to my natural form, and after a while I went back off to the tea rooms, found myself a little waiter called Elliot, sent him off to dreamland and took his form. Then I waited, waited until your son Paul had his own son, then I came back, didn't I, Jacob. Did you enjoy that cup of cocoa, my little sleeping beauty? And when you fell asleep, I took your form. No one to help you now. The Doctor's not here, so there's no happy ending.
The 100 Days of the Doctor by Paul Cornell
The Tardis dematerialises.
And we're finally on our way.
Well, I never thought bargaining for our lives could be so tiresome.
I told you I could answer any question the Inquisitor of Shram put to me.
Yes, but did you have to do it without hesitation, deviation or repetition?
I like a challenge.
Hmm.
Is something the matter, young lady?
There are times when er. No, best left unsaid.
Times when what?
When I wish that you were
Mmn,, different?
Well
I think if I have one defining characteristic, it's exactly that. I'm different from everyone. I'm even different from every other me, and who else can say that?
This is, broadly speaking, the sort of thing I wish you were different from.
Oh. I see. Well.
Now I've gone and hurt your feelings.
Not at all. You'd never do that. No, no, I was just about to go and put the kettle on. I think a nice cup of argh!
Doctor? Doctor, what's wrong?
Ah! I seem to have lost control of. Can't move my legs. Evelyn, stay back. My arm's moving of its own volition. Don't let me harm you.
What can I do? Doctor?
(possessed) Ah, there. We have control of the speech centres and the mouth. That was a particularly difficult battle. Good evening, Doctor Evelyn Smythe. We are the Teksinurens.
I beg your pardon?
We are an intelligent virus that has infested the Doctor and multiplied to the extent of now being able to control him. He's still perfectly aware. See? He's blinking at you.
What do you want?
We are a revenge weapon. The Doctor caused great irritation to our creators, the Grand Teks of the Tharsis Acumen.
The Tharsis Acumen?
So they employed an assassin to fire a microscopic dart containing a culture of us into his skin.
What? When did that happen?

We haven't been given that information, and we wouldn't tell you if we had. Over the next hundred days, we'll be gradually shutting down the Doctor's biological systems in such a way as to cause him the maximum possible agony.
That, that's monstrous!
This is the price for offending against the Tharsis Acumen. We now return control of the Doctor's body, and we will set off towards his kidneys. Good day to you.
Doctor gasps.
Doctor. Doctor. Doctor, did you hear all that?
(normal) Yes. Yes, and I can feel that it's true.
We must get you to a hospital.
The hospital doesn't exist that can treat this condition. I have one hundred days to live. Or rather, they've made the mistake of giving me one hundred days to save myself.
Here, let me, let me help you up.
Effort.
Now, who are these Tharsis people?

The Tharsis Acumen are a technocracy, a civilisation ruled by scientists. And whoever thought that might be a good idea need their head examining. You should see the bureaucracy. Getting good seats at the opera took decades.
Is that what you tried to do? I mean, is that why they hate you?

No, this is not all because I got annoyed with some bald bean-counter at a ticket agency and told him what he could do with his beans, although I did. This is because I found out the Acumen were experimenting on prisoners. Some of the scientists involved were in the box next to me and I could hear them chattering all through the encores. I got myself thrown into jail, met some fascinating people, formed a small theatre group, performed Brecht for the Governors, excelled as Mother Courage, had drinks with the Commandant, did a little fiddling with his desk top computers, and freed the political prisoners into the sewers.
Obviously.
You asked the virus the right question. When and where did I get shot?
You don't know?
My abilities don't stretch to sensing the impact of microscopic darts. Playing microscopic darts, on the other hand, for instance against the great protozoan champion Ronny One-Cell Amoeboid.
You're making it up.
Yes.
Because you're very scared.

Yes. I must think. The Tharsis Acumen only lasted for a few centuries. They never developed time travel, and their influence was limited to one spiral arm of the Milky Way. Now, calculating how long it would take for the virus to infest me, say the last ten years or so.
Well, what do all those numbers mean?
They're all the places within the range of their assassin where I've landed during that time.
That's a lot.
We have a hundred days. Best get moving. Especially since, oh dear.
What?
I've just felt a sudden twinge in my kidneys.
Walking outdoors.
So this first past you we're going to see isn't you. Oh dear, a strict grammarian really should not become a time traveller.

This will be one of those mes that I'm different from. Now remember, I was in a former incarnation when I attended this particular celebration, the inauguration of the Three-Bodied Lustrousness of the Vix.
How different is this you exactly?
Well, I don't want to speak ill of him. You should make up your own mind. He's interested in sport, of all things. Terrible dress sense.
I like him already.
The Doctor cries out in pain.
Are you all right?
Oh, Evelyn. In the next few weeks you will doubtless see me subject to all manner of minor moments of weakness. I would much appreciate it if you didn't mention every wince and stumble!
I shall try not to.
I'm sorry. There was no cause for that. I shouldn't be grumpy when there's hardly even any pain.
You know, the other day when I was complaining
It's forgotten.
I had such an ache in the small of my back from all that time we'd been standing in front of the Inquisitor of Shram.
Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't realise.
And you never said that I shouldn't be grumpy with you. You grump as much as you like. Oh, sounds like the party's in full swing. Is that you?
Yes. And those are my companions, Peri and Erimem.
Where?
Just left of, well, me.
Pretty girls.
Possibly.
And you're rather a dashing young man. And so
What?
Thin.
We agreed we could grumble. I didn't say stick the knife in.
How is it possible for you to be someone else? I mean, someone with a different personality. When you learn something, when you have life experiences, don't those things make you a particular way?
Yes, as with you. But when one regenerates, one takes those same lessons and sees them from a different angle.
So it's like joining the Brownies.
The ultimate mystery of the Time Lords is like signing on with a girls junior Scout Troop? That's one of the most spectacular similes I have ever heard attempted.
Hmm. When one joins the Brownies, ones attitude to say knitting changes immediately because of the prospect of earning a badge. The same experience, the same skills, seen from a different angle.
Every now and then you astonish me.
You've got your arm round one of the pretty girls now.
Entirely platonically.
What kind of badge were you trying to earn back then?
The all things to all men badge.
He seems lovely. Everyone likes him.
The Doctor cries out.
Doctor.
Just my leg. Oh! They wanted to remind me of how old they're making this body. Ah! It's easing now. Just a warning shot.
The virus must have realised what we're doing, that we're on to it. Here, come on. Lean on me.
Thanks.
We were talking about you being liked.

Being liked is not the be-all and end-all of what I'm about. I'm about being many different things at once, continuing in all sorts of different ways, including especially the unpopular ways. You know as well as I do what's right is often, well, usually, the exact opposite of what the majority thinks it is.
He does irk you, doesn't he?

Hmm? Not him. The way the universe treated him. Being him was like a holiday. A very wonderful holiday. Ah, feeling a bit better now. Thank you. I think I can stand on my own two feet again. Now, we have to search the crowd for a potential assassin. You go that way, I'll go this. Meet you on the other side.
What if I run into the other you?
I don't remember it happening, so best not to.
I doubt you would have remembered me amongst all the pretty girls.
Oh, if I had met you, I would have remembered.
I haven't seen anyone. What about you?
I thought I saw something just out of the corner of my eye, but no, could be a trick of the light.
Boom! Screams.
Is that the assassin?

No. No, I remember this is what happened. One of the Three Bodies of the Lustrousness turned out to want all the power. It set up the party as a trap. But I turned the tables. He reacts so quickly, that one of me. He's got a good bunch travelling with him, too. Look at that. Erimem's grabbed a sword, she's rallying people, stopping them running.
Brains as well as beauty.

She was such a friend to Peri. That made all the difference in those days. You should have seen the change in her when Erimem arrived. They sparkled in each other's company. Made me very content, a ship of bright young things.
Doctor, I know all this has already happened and it turned out for the best, but
Yes, they're coming this way. Come on, let's go and see some more of me, quickly.
Laser fire.
Heavy rain.
Six more planets, six more sightings of you, no sign of an assassin. And on one of those worlds we had to hang around for a week while you were painting.
Hmm, seven whole days.
How are you feeling?
I'm trying to control the pain by meditating, which might be why the virus has given me a very distracting headache.
Oh. Which you are we going to see now?
I'm not sure. I don't remember having been here. Shh. There's someone up ahead. Quick, behind here.
Is that you? The one being held at gunpoint?
The little man in the hat. Yes, I've met him before. He's my next incarnation.
Your next? Well, must be strange to know that.
And I think I can anticipate your next question.
If he's there, then surely you're going to be fine.
No, because Time is infinitely changeable, and I could just die. And if I do, he ceases to exist as well. Why are we here? Ah, of course.
Of course what?
Don't you see? The Tardis must have included all its future landings in the map it gave us.
You mean it knows where it's going to go?
Apparently. Interesting. And this hugely complicates our task. This can't be where I was
shot with the virus. And we're going to have to sort through endless times like this, wasting the precious days I have left.
Can't you remember where you've been?
Oh, where haven't I been? And I think the virus is deliberately damaging my memory cells. They're oh, what's the word. Oh, I see. Very funny.
Anyway, there's no point in staying here. Come on. Doctor?
Look at him. So sure of himself. Always a step ahead. Always prepared to do things I'd never do.
Are you sure? He seems a rather jolly man.
It looks as though he's made another family for himself. That's often when I'm happiest.
Oh.
Present company excepted. Those two, the girl and the boy.
Another dashing young chap. And she looks as though she can hold her own. She seems very grown up for one of your friends. Present company excepted. They look like brother and sister.
Look, he's waiting for them to do something to save the situation. He's teaching them. Unlike him. From what I've heard, he was always blowing up planets, and they call me the aggressive one.
Who call you that?
The audience.
What?
Those who pay attention to my travels.
Are you hallucinating? There are people watching us?
Or listening to us.
Listening?

They say the pictures are better when you're listening. And in the case of Gallifreyan Time- Space Visualisers that's often literally the case. I'm talking about the Time Lords. Always interested in what I'm getting up to.
I remember your home. All that political intrigue. I found it absolutely fascinating. Wish I could listen in on them. Do you think this audience of yours could help you?
Look, that Doctor's friends, they're distracting the men with the guns. Any minute now.
Gunshots and grunts.
There we go.
With a baseball bat. Doctor, isn't it time we
Yes, yes, yes. We must go. Evelyn?
Yes? What's the matter?
Well, it's just that I'd rather like to see some more mes from the future before my one hundred days are up. I feel as if they may be the only future I have. That's a bad sign, isn't it?
You aren't going to give up hope. I'm not going to let you. Even if I have to find my own baseball bat.
This looks like a bit of a dive.
The American frontier in the 1870s. Within the reach of our assassin.
If he's one of your future selves, we turn on our heels and leave. Agreed?
As we have done on every previous occasion.
Yes, but you've been taking your time turning. Why is it never your first four selves we run into?
Sheer coincidence. There are a lot of stories to be told, you know, with the rest of us.
So how do we tell which one is you in a room where every man's wearing a frock coat?
I'm the one not carrying a gun.
The one playing poker, you mean? Oh, but there's two of you. The same you.
It happens. If the circumstances are safe, then it can even be fun, especially with a game like that.
You can be pretty sure one won't remember the others cards. He looks nice.
Will you stop saying that? You're making it sound like you drew the short straw.
I mean he looks charming, relaxed, as though he has all the time in the world.
Most of us live a long time. There was a time when I thought this incarnation was going to be short and sweet, but then I thought I'd been given the gift of
Getting old gracefully?
Older. It's good to have mellowed, to have had the chance to explore, to be me.
Stop talking as if it's nearly over.
Indeed. Of course. We should go. Those two with him are quite something, aren't they? And those dresses, with feathers in their hair. One posh as you like, the other one a bit more mainstream.
What's that in the corner? Doctor, is that the assassin? That thing that looks like. It did, it moved.

It's all right, he knows about it. Both of them. They keep looking over to him. I do believe he must be a companion too. I've never had a non-humanoid travel with me before. So many differences. Good for him. Argh!
Oh, are you all right?
I'm ah! It'll be all right. Must be. I've got to make it all right for all their sakes. How many days has it been?
I'm not keeping count.
Yes you are.
Sixty five. Come on. Come on, if I have to drag you.
Well, there I am. This me. And you with me. Over there on the sand dune, do you remember?
How could I forget? Yes, those dratted sand creatures. Oh.
What's the matter?
I was just looking at the contrast between that version of you and
I have become rather pale and strained, haven't I? The virus has taken its toll, I'm afraid.
How are you feeling?

The pain is now really quite extreme, in every joint, in every muscle. And the damage that it must be doing to my internal organs I really can't describe, so best not to, en? We must carry on while there's still hope. Now, this is when we helped out that archaeological expedition, isn't it.
The one funded by
Braxiatel, yes.
Could he help us?

The only thing he'll be good for is being condescending to me. Oh, you know the sort of thing. How could I get myself into such a mess? This is the price I pay for my adventuring, blah, blah, blah. Oh, Brax was always the sensible one. Up to his neck in Gallifrey, then on that planet where he built his collection, he stayed put and looked after his own.
I must say, I didn't like the look of him. Untrustworthy, I thought.
Oh, I don't know about that. Ah, there's the leader of his expedition. What was her name again?

Professor Bernice Summerfield. We had some wonderful chats while you were out searching for those creatures. She drinks like a fish, mind you. Had some very good gin, but no tonic. Relationship issues which she said she wouldn't talk about, and then did after having had a few. She's really lived, that girl. She's had adventures for such a long time. Oh, the sun's so bright here I can hardly make them out.
Did you see? Something moving there, in the shadows. Yes, there, definitely.
It is a shadow.
Follow it. Come on!
In there. It went into that cave.
Oh blast, he's gone. Right in front of us. We were so close. A ripple in the air as he went. A sophisticated camouflage device, then a teleport to a waiting spacecraft somewhere nearby.
So were you just shot?

No. No, I'm sure he didn't do it this time. He couldn't take a chance with us wearing those long desert robes. One thing about an intelligent virus, it's very expensive to manufacture. The assassin only gets one shot. Let me check something. (whirring) Yes. He's put a tracer on me. On the old me, I mean. Or the slightly younger one. Wonderful. This narrows it down. We only need to check the planets I visited after this one. How many days left?
Sixteen.
That, that's plenty of time. Of course it is. Come on.
Tardis in flight.
So, limiting it to only planets after that one, still within the range.
That can't leave very many.
Indeed. It leaves just one. Now. Argh!
Doctor?
No!
No what?
The Doctor in extreme pain.

Doctor, that's not you hitting those controls, is it. It's that virus making you do it. Stop. Get away from the console. We must be getting close to you, you foul thing, or you wouldn't be trying to stop us.
The Doctor gasps.
Oh, Evelyn, thank you. It's me again. It made me sabotage the controls, sent us where? Oh no.
What is it?
Sideways in time, into the gap between realities. It's like a labyrinth of what might have been. We're going to need help to find our way out of this.
Then let's get out there and find some.
Cheers and applause.
So that's over, then. We did it, didn't we. We saved the United Nations.
We stopped that annoying man from deploying his Krynoid pods, and now we're getting back to the Tardis as fast as possible.

We're all different. The same in a lot of ways. Such a different me. What could be true? Ah, at least these other mes will survive, these parallel mes. If things had happened differently. How fascinating they are.
He gave you the dimensional control from his Tardis so that we could get out of here.
He actually likes his exile, likes being with the Brigadier and that new version of UNIT.
I think so. They kept on and on about their days in Hong Kong.
Ah, talking of days.
One left.
Evelyn
That's still one. Come on. We must get back to the Tardis.
Tardis door closes.
Doctor, come on. Plug that control box in, start this thing moving, get us back into our own universe. Stand up.
They'll all keep on going. UNIT, Sarah Jane, all those continuing stories. They don't need me.
Yes, they do. Now come on. You'll come on if I have to drag you.
(groans) Satisfied?
Not yet. Not until you've won.
The Tardis materialises. Tardis door opens. Walking on gravel.
This is the place?
Tardis door closes.
That afternoon we spent just flying kites. Look at the pile of them over there. So many different ones the locals wanted us to try.
(in pain) One of my favourite days, and something bad had to happen on it.
There we are, on the horizon. Oh Doctor, how are we going to see the assassin? This mass of air, home to so many lifeforms on this world, but it's so clear. He'll be able to hide perfectly.
What's that? Are my eyes
No. It's a cloud of steam, of volcanic smoke. But, I don't remember that.
Evelyn, concentrate. Look for a shape.
There! A shadow, on that ridge. He's taking aim at you.
Well, he's not going to get the chance. Grab that kite.
What are you going to do?
I'm glad we spent this day learning how to fly them. Watch this. Yah! No, you are not in control of my body. You can't stop me!
Doctor, he's about to fire.
Shot, gurgle.
Got him!
But Doctor, he'd already shot you.
Follow me.
Running, struggle.
Gotcha!
Too late, Time Lord. You've got me, but look at you over there, on the way back to your Tardis, all unknowing. The virus is already in your system.
It was never my intention to stop you shooting me. I'm here to take revenge on my murderer.
What?
But everyone knows you don't kill.

The look on my companion's face should tell you that after the hundred days we've just experienced, she knows that when it comes to knowing what I might or might not do, all bets are off. Do you know what this is?
A medical container.
And inside is the very same virus with which you just shot me. (glass breaks) Have a good sniff of that.
